div.head: Appendix: statistics
div.p: All statistics in this appendix are generated dynamically by my Python script statistics.py, which processes the XML code of the edition.

div.head: Statistics on variant types and subtypes

list.item:
The 'actual' variants ('V', henceforth) are . In this number
I count types "substantive", "transposition" (counted once, henceforth) and "orthographic" (except @subtype="case")
I do not count types "punctuation", "gap-in-ms", "illegible-in-ms", or the special case @type="orthography"/@subtype="case".

Of all actual variants (V):
% are substantive (SV henceforth)
% are orthographic (not counting @subtype="case"; OVEC henceforth)
% are transpositions.

The following subtypes have been identified for substantive variants (@type="substantive"):
, i.e. % of all actual variants (V), have @subtype="missing-in-ms" (integrations)
(% of V) have @subtype="missing-in-print" (expunctions)
(% of V) have @subtype="num-num" (two different numerals)
(% of V) have @subtype="fs" (confusion between 'f' and 's').

The following subtypes have been identified for orthographic variants (@type="orthographic"):
, % of all actual variants (V), have @subtype="double"
(% of V) have @subtype="h"
(% of V) have @subtype="y"
(% of V) have @subtype="tc"
(% of V) have @subtype="case" (however, these are no actual MS variants: see paragraph 'Case variants' above)
(% of V) have @subtype="mn"
(% of V) have @subtype="num-word"
(% of V) have @subtype="mpn"
(% of V) have @subtype="pb"
(% of V) have @subtype="word-segmentation"
(% of V) have @subtype="ph"
(% of V) have @subtype="ae"
(% of V) have @subtype="ch"
(% of V) have @subtype="dm-mm"
(% of V) have @subtype="hi-y"
(% of V) have @subtype="ncx"
(% of V) have @subtype="cz"
(% of V) have @subtype="cq"
(% of V) have @subtype="tz"
(% of V) have @subtype="ck".

There are no subtypes of @type="transposition". So, including both substantive and orthographic variants (except @subtype="case"), for 'app's a @subtype has been identified, corresponding to % of all actual variants (V).

The typization of variants was an experimental feature of this digital edition. A higher percentage of subtypes could be identified, especially for orthographic variants, by further improving the string comparison algorithms used, but these initial results seem encouraging. Please keep in mind that algorithms (Python software) tentatively identified types and subtypes for app elements, then I reviewed them one by one manually. However, the more accurate the algorithms became, the easier and faster the review was.

div.head: Statistics on textual-critical decisions
div.p: Out of a total of 'actual' loci variantes (V, as defined above):

list.item: In cases (% of V) I agreed with the reading of the print edition used as collation exemplar (Garufi or Bonetti).
In cases (% of V) I chose a MS reading over that of the print edition.
In only cases O is the only witness providing a reading that I chose over the print edition reading. This corresponds to % of all loci variantes in which O is one of the witnesses.

Of total words in the text (calculated excluding words in 'rdg' elements')
(%) are part of a locus varians (i.e. are in 'lem' elements).
